title: Before 15 December 2021, will the U.S. either formally seek to join or formally begin renegotiations with signatories regarding the TPP or CPTPP?
preds: Seems highly unlikely at this point.
Down 2% for passage of time. —and likely BBB sucking all available attention from 46.

It seems crazy that China is now wanting to join the CPTPP, the successor to the trade agreement that the US left: https://asia.nikkei.com/Opinion/CPTPP-members-must-be-wary-of-China-s-attempt-to-join-trade-pact
There's a lot I don't understand. The clock is ticking, so I'll put my chips now on nothing happening by 15 December.
(no change) With 46 discussing bottlenecks, it might be just a step away from easier trade.
AUKUS sunk any move in this matter for now
No change in background environment here. Holding with a vanishingly slight possibility for this scenario.
Down 5% for passage of time. I think I overestimated what was possible/important for 46.

"Alex Feldman, president and chief executive of U.S.-ASEAN Business Council, said the U.S. is unlikely to join the CPTPP in the short term." Although in the long term, I think we will seek to join. https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/20/vp-kamala-harris-to-visit-singapore-vietnam-amid-us-china-tensions.html

Rather than a screeching U-turn, I have recalibrated my initial analysis due a changing view of the Biden Administration. Given that he was the vice president in Obama’s administration and that 95% of Biden’s Cabinet picks have prior government experience, compared to 32% of Trump’s team having no such experience, the inference being that Biden would unravel much of Trump’s tumultuous trade actions of withdrawing from the TPP and/or engaging with the CPTPP.
Biden’s administration has however, maintained Trump’s trade policies, perhaps due to counter China’s actions in Hong Kong, Taiwan and to a lesser extent on the border with India.
Biden’s cabinet would appear to prefer bilateral trade deals with Japan and Taiwan to counter the Chinese interest in the CPTPP. https://www.npr.org/sections/president-biden-takes-office
https://www.forbes.com/sites/stuartanderson/2021/07/07/imf-tells-biden-to-dump-trumps-tariffs/?sh=6693e0a242b3
https://asia.nikkei.com/Editor-s-Picks/Interview/Can-Biden-return-the-US-to-TPP-Does-it-matter-2-experts-explain  https://www.eastasiaforum.org/2021/06/23/reconciling-the-rhetoric-and-reality-of-bidens-trade-policy/  https://www.csis.org/analysis/cptpp-and-intellectual-property-rights-protection  https://www.aspistrategist.org.au/bidens-back-but-the-us-still-needs-to-rebuild-its-international-standing/
The regulatory landscape is against Bitcoin.
Don't expect this to happen this year but maybe after the midterms.
WSJ: Japanese officials are eyeing a backdoor approach to bring the U.S. back into regional economic cooperation, according to people familiar with their thinking.

Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership is not something the unions and some Democrats would approve. The intellectual protection is not in the trade agreement as much as the Biden WH would have wanted. The administration is more aligned to infrastructure and jobs, the latter being a more key provision to garner votes than upending the CPTPP as congressional groups are more apt to make the Strategic Competition Act of 2021 an alternative to the agreement, trade makes more jobs but the agreement is a back burner issue.

I'm becoming less convinced that the Biden administration have actually decided about either of the relevant questions here (whether to extend TPA, and if so, then whether to negotiate entry to CPTPP). My expectation now is that they will probably extend TPA, but that CPTPP will not begin this year.
revising downward 3pts to reflect passage of time & absence of news
Biden wants to normalize trade agreements with perceived allies and countries friendly to the US.

Updating because of my overconfidence in the range of 2%..10%.
Given the rising COVID concerns in the US, Biden has more pressing matters

Going to zero.  Tomorrow is April 1, closing the 90-day window for Congressional notification of intent to begin formal trade talks.  Trade Promotion Authority lapses July 1.  Today, President Biden announced a $2 Trillion infrastructure plan, which is likely to be the focus through the August recess, decreasing the likelihood of a major effort to renew TPA this year, which would certainly be required in this political environment.

Looks like they will let the TPA expire, and then spend some time thinking about negotiating a new one, and probably announce CPTPP negotiations after the 2022 elections because they seem to think it inherently costs political capital.
revising downward due to @Francis_Urquhart 's analysis: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1232859
Update on progress - The Senate confirmed Katherine Tai on March 17, 2021, by a vote of 98-0 https://ballotpedia.org/Confirmation_process_for_Katherine_Tai_for_U.S._trade_representative
Big question is if China's military stance frows more hostile during the remainder of 2021. Would TPP serve as a hemmer on China?  However, TPP would never be ratified by the current US Senate
It is too late for US, they will need to clarify restrictions first before applying to join
top level talks in Alaska last night. Have not heard the outcome yet.

There doesn't even seem to be chatter about this, and it's a sufficiently complicated issue that rushing into anything is more likely to be a bad idea than a good one.  The Current Incumbent, unlike is predecessor, is keenly aware of this.  But stay tuned--almost anything that can happen will happen these days.
Down 20% based on @Francis_Urquhart post. I still think just saying yes to TPP is low hanging fruit, but as @cdob63 says, "I'm frequently wrong."

Lowering my forecast by 9 points to 1% "yes", based on today's headline news: Katherine Tai confirmed as U.S Trade Representative.  Her staff backgrounded the Washington Post on her priorities: "Among her first tasks will be advising the president on what to do about existing tariffs on most imported Chinese products, presiding over enforcement of a new trade deal with Mexico and Canada, and seeking a negotiated end to a long-running commercial dispute with the European Union."  No mention of the CPTPP and Trade Promotion Authority expires in July.  The 90-day window for congressional notification of  the Biden administration's intent to enter negotiations will close in April with the July expiration of TPA.  I see little basis to conclude the Congress will re-authorize TPA before the deadline for this question. [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2021/03/17/tai-trade-biden/
Basing my forecast on the analysis (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1249145) by @Francis_Urquhart

Few things to consider:
Biden stated on the campaign trail that he wouldn't sign any trade deals before a investing domestically, for example an infrastructure bill. (1)
First moment a new spending bill can be passed through the senate is July with reconciliation (2)
If a spending bill fails, next moment will be in 2022
Tradedeals aren't very popular right now (3)
A trade deal in Asia would be beneficial economically and would counter China's influence in the region. (4) My prediction: the USA will probably start discussing the prospect joining TPP/CPTPP very soon behind closed doors.  Announcing the intention to formally join will probably be done when these talks are in a very advanced state. Given the nature of these talks and the amount of time usually going into such a process I don't think it very likely to be announced this year. Especially not before September.  1:

Biden seeks to re-engage with the world so this would be consistent with his general posture, but I do think the free trade consensus has weakened in the US since the administration of which he was a key part first negotiated this deal. We see early rumblings that retaliatory tariffs are being jettisoned by this administration, but the Trump trade policy has not been rejected wholesale. The administration has a full plate and pacific trade may not get as much attention. While the Obama administration was trying to pivot toward Asia, it is unclear how Biden's foreign policy agenda will emphasize different regions of the world. I'd like more clarity on what "formally begin renegotiations" entails, but on balance I am more confident than the current consensus of this group that we will seek to do just that.

-5 as we get closer to April 1, which marks the 90-day notification deadline for the July 1 expiration of Trade Promotion Authority.  After April and the closing of the 90-day window, the administration will no longer have TPA.  Further to my earlier forecast, it seems unlikely the administration can secure renewal from the Congress or that they would even ask for it.

Change: -3 Reasoning: Just checked out the nominee for U.S. trade rep (https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3123178/bidens-nominee-trade-representative-speaks-us-china). Her priorities seem to be bringing WTO cases against China and further negotiation of the deal China struck with Trump. Any bigger trade deals do not seem to be an immediate priority. However: there is some chatter about "bilateral" trade deals (https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/International-relations/Biden-s-Asia-policy/Ex-US-trade-chiefs-pin-high-TPP-hopes-on-Katherine-Tai). I think these have the same political issues, but I believe they would cause the question to be closed in the affirmative, yes? My prediction is that Biden tries to navigate this after midterms and later into his term.

Bringing this down from 5% to 2% - Sec. State Blinken said "We will only pursue new trade deals after we have made investments in American workers and communities." If he's serious, that suggests to me that the infrastructure bill will have to be enacted first, which will also take time.

Apparently, the U.S. will have to join urgently before China does. I suppose there's not enough room for both of them in this club. https://jamestown.org/program/xi-jinping-boosts-the-partys-control-and-his-own-authority/

(no change) I mostly agree and sort of pay attention to constraints on some version of renegotiations (or starting related to the CPTPP) but I also think all the Biden adminstration has to do to "rejoin" for purposes of this question is to say they back it again and submit it to the US Senate for ratification.

High probability that North American trade policy gets the quicker focus, and therefore the quicker resolution with fewer players. The broader Trans-Pacific agreements will take longer to develop with more parties involved. 
Katherin Tai's confirmation hearing began on 25th Feb, and the median duration of a senate confirmation is ~ 70 days.
We could assume that this confirmation process may be significantly quicker, and we could reasonably expect her confirmation to occur before the Senate recesses for holidays from end-of-July to beginning of September.
The 90 day notification process would need to occur before 15th September at the latest, as mentioned by Francis_Urquhart .
I'm trusting Francis too.  He has some very thoughtful analysis.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1232859.
Hard to see how this fits into broader political context and trade priorities at the moment for the new administration.
The US prefers bilateral trades as opposed to larger trade pacts in the future. This limits their loss and with 12.2% they are not a big exporting country compared to Germany >47%  and China.

Francis's comment was very compelling. I'll trust his word and not do my own due dilligence abt the 90 day time frame. the 90 day time frame is significant. Katherine Tai won't be confirmed until late-march given the covid bill will likely happen first. I still believe it's not a matter of "if" but a matter of when. But with this new information, the answer to when is much later.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1232859

The biden admin has stated it will not look to make new trade deals at the start of this administration. BUT, if there was one trade deal other than NAFTA or whatever it's called now, it would be a trade deal in the asia pacific. As news outlets have reported, Biden admin has spent its first month spending a lot of time re-kindling relationships in asia/the asian pacific. The middle east not so much. To me, the question is not if, it's a question of when this gets done.

Biden will revisit this at some point. When is the question. His choice for agriculture nominee makes it look more likely. 
The two articles below are the strongest in favour. The against articles all seem to say Biden would want it, just is not sure how it would go down.  It looks to be the toss of a coin, with maybe a little more in favour of yes. 54% https://thediplomat.com/2021/02/japan-expects-biden-to-rejoin-the-tpp/ https://truthout.org/articles/bidens-agriculture-nominee-could-bring-us-back-into-trans-pacific-partnership/

One reason why the USA may not join is that Biden does not want to alienate a sections of society that feel strongly about trade liberalization. Certainly given the effect of COVID on the US, people may strongly oppose the opening of boarders and free trade. Biden himself stated that “He wants to be a president for all Americans” and wants to reduces party division. 
There are incentives for joining. The reduction in tariffs would help domestic businesses. I could see a situation where the the COVID stimulus package fails and many turn to a free trade agreement to stimulate the economy. Also, an escalation of the China-USA tension may cause the US to seek the tactical benefits of closer relationships with China’s neighbours. 
However, I do not think that China-US tensions will escalate and the turmoil that has happened in past year may mean that Biden’s first year in office is focused domestically and while the TPP may help many issues, I do not think it likely course of action.

The issues confronting the Biden administration are threefold.
1)	Economic. Tariffs can be reduced to encourage trade and American manufacture.
2)	Domestic. There is a fear amongst Unions and Democrats that blue collar workers will suffer by the transfer of jobs to lower labour cost locations.
3)	Influence. The ability of the US to enhance its influence in the Asia-Pacific area to arrest the potential domination and rise of China. The Biden administration has indicated a desire to re-engage with the CPTPP, but domestic attitudes may interfere with this with the concern to detrimentally effect the blue-collar communities.
‘Despite the domestic and international difficulties, joining the CPTPP will likely be a Biden administration goal, particularly with an internationalist like Tony Blinken as Secretary of State.
Biden has already expressed a desire to do so. By re-entering a key Asian trade deal, Washington can aim to create the gold standard for free trade in the region, while also bringing together its closest allies.’ 
Biden stated during the primaries, that he would potentially renegotiate TTP and address the concerns of protections for workers and the environment.
Another tempting reason for engaging with CPTPP is the possibility of strengthening Taiwan’s status in the area in light of China’s continuing aggression towards the island.
The TPP could create a linkage between US military and Asian economic integration that may stem the Chinese commercial growth and its destabilising activities.
I will suggest that the positives of joining outweigh the negatives especially an increase of influence over the rise of China, that Biden will begin negotiations to join the trade agreement.  https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/commentary/us-china-rcep-tpp-cptpp-trade-joe-biden-join-trans-pacific-13635230  https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/11/control-risks-on-biden-administration-rejoining-tpp-trade-deal.html https://www.fdiintelligence.com/article/79154  https://www.forbes.com/sites/taxnotes/2020/12/22/its-not-just-the-taxes-and-tariffs-why-biden-should-reconsider-the-trans-pacific-partnership/?sh=480b32fb1051  https://www.cfr.org/in-brief/bidens-first-foreign-policy-move-reentering-international-agreements  https://providencemag.com/2021/02/america-might-need-rejoin-tpp-trans-pacific-partnership-joe-biden/  https://thediplomat.com/2021/01/china-wont-rush-to-join-cptpp-neither-should-the-us/  https://www.china-briefing.com/news/what-will-a-biden-administration-mean-forasia-trade-policy-in-2021/  https://ustr.gov/sites/default/files/TPP-Economic-Benefits-Fact-Sheet.pdf  Youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y63ncbpBDLI
It must happen. Most likely 32 March 2021.

This seems very unlikely to me. Left leaning Democrats did not seem to favor the TPP in general when it was originally being debated, and it seems that there's even more trade skepticism in congress now. Trade deals have really taken a beating from both sides, and there doesn't seem to be much appetite for that right now. And @Francis_Urquhart has a great breakdown here on the details: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1232859

It seems like it is certainly a goal at some point, given the bipartisan urging for the US to get back in: https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2020/12/87540181c3dd-us-experts-urge-rejoining-pacific-free-trade-deal-amid-chinas-rise.html   Also there are the economic concerns raised by Biden in his phone call with Xi, so you know it's a priority: https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/02/10/readout-of-president-joseph-r-biden-jr-call-with-president-xi-jinping-of-china/  However, the Biden Administration has a lot on its plate, and the pick for US Trade Representative, Katherine Tai, hasn't been confirmed yet by the Senate. So I agree with the others that it's a tight deadline.

@Francis_Urquhart seems spot on to me. His TLDR is that there is actually a much smaller window for this to happen. People should also remember that even Hillary Clinton backed away from TPP. Biden has said nothing about it on the campaign trail and is unlikely to push it in the early months of his administration. The deal is not politically popular and thus I doubt it will be negotiated before midterms.  https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/11/control-risks-on-biden-administration-rejoining-tpp-trade-deal.html
There are a lot of corporations to whom Biden is beholden who are very interested in pushing this agreement through
This may sound silly. But this must happen prior to an informal G7 meeting. Why because of RCEP. DIME!  Don’t sit at the table until this is on paper with non-invisible ink.
The White House will focus on domestic issues for the first year or more.
US won't ask formally to restart negotiations if it is not going to be accepted. Political situation has changed in other countries such as Mexico since the US withdrew so it might not be so soon.
Joe Biden doesn’t seem that he will rejoin,but US trade with TPP countries values at 1.5 trillion dollars.Also,to add to that,many Democrats and joe think that trade will not pass Congress.
Corporations want this especially IP protections - but too many progressives hate the TPP.

Thanks to @JGunnCool  I now know I couldn't have been more wrong about my earlier assertion regarding the wording of "formally begin renegotiation."  It does have a legal meaning!  And that new understanding greatly changes my view on this question. Under TPA, the administration of the day has to formally notify Congress 90 days prior to commencing negotiations on a trade agreement.  I'm not a trade expert, but I could have easily and should have more closely read that CRS brief to which I offered a link!  If we do not see a Congressional notification by April 1, then this question is unlikely to be a "yes" within its terms of reference, even if the administration makes lots of news with a high-profile public diplomacy push to talk about trade in Asia.    Combined with my better understanding of TPA mechanics, I would note President Biden announced a major policy review of all national security agencies on February 4 with a central goal being refocusing foreign policy and national security agencies toward promoting the U.S. middle class.[1]  In particular, the memo states that a so-called "Deputies Committee" meeting will take place by April 4 to "discuss challenges and opportunities for refocusing United States foreign policy to meet the needs of the American middle class."  The Deputies Committee is one step below the Principals Committee composed of the president, vice president, and cabinet secretaries who meet to decide U.S. policy. Further research also pointed to many statements during the campaign that a Biden administration would prioritize domestic recovery before embarking on "disentangling" the former administration's trade deals.[2] Another strike against a "yes" on this question now that I have a better understanding is that the USTR nominee who would lead negotiation strategy has not been confirmed by the Senate.  If she is confirmed in February, that still only leaves two months until the 90-day window for TPA would close. I am also pessimistic that any path exists right now to extend TPA when it expires in July.  Even without the filibuster, which still exists, I don't see Sherrod Brown, Bernie Sanders, Kirsten Gillibrand, Sheldon Whitehouse, Ed Markey, Cory Booker, Amy Klobuchar, or Elizabeth Warren voting to extend TPA right now without a knock down drag out fight over incorporating climate change and even tougher labor protections into the negotiating authority granted for TPA.[3]  It is hard to see enough Republicans in the Senate being willing to break from the past president's trade policy to counteract the large number of Democrats above. In light of this new understanding on my part of that crucial word "formally," I am lowering my forecast significantly.    [1] https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/02/04/memorandum-revitalizing-americas-foreign-policy-and-national-security-workforce-institutions-and-partnerships/
[2] https://www.politico.com/news/2020/08/20/for-biden-untangling-trumps-trade-wars-takes-backseat-to-economy-398748
[3] https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/2/18/18215442/2020-democratic-presidential-candidates-policies-trade; 
https://thehill.com/policy/finance/478636-here-are-the-10-senators-who-voted-against-trumps-north-american-trade-deal

From CFR: "The United States is “not ready domestically to jump back into that agreement,” says Cutler, noting that it will take time for Biden to navigate disagreement within his party on trade..." and the signatories are in no hurry either. The changes made to get from TPP to CPTPP (less generous provisions for intellectual property rights and limits on arbitration for investor-state disputes) were the provisions pushed by the multinational corporations and resisted by both US progressives and by the signatories of the CPTPP. There will be much less enthusiasm and push from the multinational corporations to re-join CPTPP, and there is still a lot of concern from labor and environmental groups. The Biden administration has plenty on its plate already. I can't see them putting a lot of resources or energy into this effort this year.
Biden will try, he will have some resistance from left and congressional Republicans.

The key to my strong view in favor of "yes" is related to the formulation of the question.  I am quite pessimistic about the U.S.'s early rejoining of the CPTPP in the current political environment.  It is unlikely that any coalition of senators exists to ratify the CPTPP in its current form, given labor union opposition and Republicans who continue to support the former president's trade policies.  Additionally, President Biden has made supporting the American middle class a central feature of his foreign policy.[1]  Most credible, independent analysis of the CPTPP find it would lead to U.S. job losses in manufacturing while modestly increasing GDP and overall employment through increases in the agriculture and services sector.  Manufacturing jobs in export-oriented companies are the holy grail of middle class prosperity, since they pay well above average for low-skilled workers, something that the new administration is not likely to treat lightly.  Nonetheless, in diplomacy, announcing symbolic but non-binding gestures, like commencing trade talks, are a low-cost way to signal priorities to allies, partners, and competitors.  "Formally" is doing a lot of work in the question's construction on beginning renegotiation.  It really has no legal meaning that I'm aware in this context.  Congressionally-conferred Trade Promotion Authority to guarantee an up or down vote without amendments on trade agreements in the Senate will expire in July 2021.[2]  If we get to August 2021 without any announcement by the administration and TPA continues to be lapsed, it would not be a good sign for entering renegotiation of the CPTPP.  Trade partners generally do not wish to negotiate with American administrations lacking TPA, given the likelihood of a death by a thousand amendments for trade treaties. China's muscular role in the region, especially inking its own RCEP trade pact create strong incentives for the new Biden administration to find ways to symbolize a return to an active strategic presence in the region.  Biden said during the campaign that the idea was a good one but that he would seek renegotiation to protect workers and the environment.[3] [1] ttps://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/articles/29409/biden-s-foreign-policy-for-the-middle-class-takes-shape
[2] https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/IF/IF10038
[3] https://www.cfr.org/in-brief/bidens-first-foreign-policy-move-reentering-international-agreements

Up 15% to be above the consensus. All opportunities related to re-normalizing US trade policy will probably be on the table. A competent, if not perfect, administration can walk and chew gum at the same time.
By December, Current major priorities will be partially addressed at a minimum.

The Biden administration will not rush to rejoin the TPP. Instead, the administration will start by focusing on domestic issues, such as the COVID-19 pandemic as well as the revitalization of American industries. Persistent opposition to economic globalization in the Rust Belt will force Biden to tread lightly while keeping one eye on the 2022 mid-term election.
More likely that not the US will work to renegotiate  CPTPP

This looks like a complete no-brainer for the US. China is making noises about joining, if the US joins first they can block them. They would also get a trade deal with the UK, which they lack, since the UK applied last week to join CPTPP. This can form the basis of a serious economic alliance to oppose Chinese expansionism and prevent them from obtaining global hegemony in this century. Therefore, I am very uncertain whether Biden will go down this route, since he has gotten the vast majority of his foreign policy positions wrong throughout his career, and Blinken has a similarly mediocre record. It seems what they are currently saying is they want to deal with coronavirus first. That will last longer than 2021. If they think this is a politically risky move then they should actually do it during the pandemic, since the news cycle is particularly fast now and they are far away from the midterm elections, but again, I doubt their judgement.

President Biden has stated that he intends to have the United States rejoin the world. He also supported the TPP when he was Vice President [1], and has stated that the US would rejoin the TPP under his administration [2]. Thus, I predict a 100% probability that the US will formally begin negotiations on re-entering the TPP by 15 Dec 2021. But Biden and Congress is busy with many priorities that are higher on the priority list.
Initial forecast. Almost all reasonable economists think bailing was a mistake. Wish 44 hadn't been born in Kenya ;-)
Unlikely unless it is renamed something other than TPP or a big push to sell it to the public occurs. It is still political poison amongst populists on the left and right.
